body.p:
At length I enjoy a day's ease from toil and of
comparative coolness, leaving me sufficient time and
energy after the exhausting and incessant heat of over
five months duration to drop you a few lines; not
in answer to your last, for I have mislaid your letter,
put in some safe place, which has escaped my memory.

If the situation at Savannah did not materially
interfere with your high position as the leader and
exponent of orthodoxy, that is, if the acceptance of it
did not, in a measure shelve you, by consigning you,
to so comparatively insignificant a sphere, I would
be the first to advise you to quit Philadelphia, and
honorably retire to a spot where your influence might
still be felt, and when the duties would be to you
light and easy, and above all a resting place to
breathe in and enjoy yourself after your laborious and
toilsome career. Could you not manage to issue the
Occident there? That you should have a disinclination
to leave Pa. when your world-wide reputation

has been established, is natural; but remember it
is not with your Hebrew, but Hebrew. You can without
desertions the holy cause still fulfil the command, Hebrew
Hebrew, and be as useful as ever, tho the locality
be smaller. You have earned your olium, and if you
can enjoy it ?, why not avail yourself
of so seasonable an opportunity, in the society of those
who would hail your coming with enthusiasm, and in
a climate more genial to your partly worn out constitution,
enfeebled by excessive work in the cause of your people.
I think you ought, and so will every true friend of yours.
We don't want you to drop at your post from sheer fatigue;
say then to us Hebrew, and accept the post.

Orthodoxy, from the stand-point, I view it, cannot long
maintain its ground in America, nor elsewhere concessions
must be made; not in the homeopathic doses you wish
to administer, but in heroic quantities, as the M Dr
say Hebrew and a Hebrew are not enough, and as Mr Moïse
justly observes if you concede them, the precedent is
at once established for granting more. You have fought
a good fight, but overwhelming odds are against you.

If the fabric of historical Judaism is to be saved
from utter demolition, for, on the score of Scriptural
Judaism, I have no fear, fair compromises must be
made. I have long held out against changes by
individual congregations, but our orthodox leaders
give no sign of life, utter no sound, to cheer their
supporters and followers. The pressure from without
increases daily in intensity, and the faithful Hebrew
must either yield to the demands made, or give
room to others who will effect a complete bouleverse
ment of the existing state of things.

I have been interrupted for some hours by the
sad tidings of the loss of the Evening Star. Some of the
passengers said to be lost have relatives among my
congregation, but I declined to give Hebrew until their
fate had been ascertained. I have however very little
hope of their being alive.

Revenons à nos moutons. Have you read the articles
in the “Archives Israelites” written by Cohen, Chief Rabbi
in Algiers, during the last few months? Their fairness is
indisputable and their accuracy has not been impeached,
and, what is more, cannot be. His account of the Hebrew

particularly of the second day Hebrew which I had been
taught to believe had been kept in Jerusalem from the days
of Ezra has no such historical basis, but dates from a
very recent period; and, to my astonishment, I learned for
the first time that on that day, the common daily prayers
are said in Jerusalem, and not those for the festival.
I had heard before that some of the Hebrew from the Holy City
came to Synagogue in London on Hebrew with their Tephillin on.
Really, therefore if our orthodox guides do not bestir them
selves and clean up the obscurities which envelop our
minhagim, particularly their origin and history, much
will be swept away which should be retained. A book
has been in my library for years, called Hebrew, which
curiosity induced me lately to peruse, as it is frequently quoted
by Zumy? in his Gottes dienstliche Vorträge, and not alone the
reasoning of the author, but the support it receives from
dist quotations of distinguished writers, truly orthodox,
have entirely shaken my faith in the Rabbinism of
the middle ages, little as I believed in it before. I had
often begun to read this volume, but it seemed to be exclusively
directed against the stassidim?, and so it did not
interest me, whereas now I am going thro' it carefully.

It seems that the converse of Hebrew was the rule of
our guides in the middle ages, and that either they did not
understand the sayings and doings of their revered predecessors,
the Hebrew who view large souled and enlightened men,
and but introduced a sort of asceticism into Judaism, public &
private, or they assumed an authority which modern research
questions, and refuses any longer to tolerate. Do not imagine
by my writing in this strain that I am going to turn ultra
Reformer. The second days are still kept here, and the Synagogue
attended by a few, just sufficient to make minyan. With the
exception of five Jewish stores, and the remainder are closed
by my people on that day the Sabbath, tho' among them are rabid Reformers
who keep aloof from the Synag: except on on Rosh Hashanah and
Kippoor, until certain modifications in the Ritual and public
worship are sanctioned by me. I must yield, or extremes
will be resorted to, whose consequences would imperil the conserv-
ation of important and fundamental things. What conscientious
pangs might have been spared men struggling like myself to
preserve the unity of formula in our worship had we been
backed by an orthodox Synod of learned & enlightened
Rabbis, prepared to direct claims for changes into a channel

or stream whose waters might have fructified Judaism.
I say it with pain, with agony, that the want of such a Synod
has sent? Judaism to tatters, that it has encouraged rationalism
in its destructive tendencies in the west, and promoted the
growth of that abominable stassidism? in the east. I have
some true and good men among my people, who have travelled
and seen much of our various communities in France,
Germany, Austria, and other parts of Europe. They are men
attached to the old system still, with all its admitted defects,
and they lament with me the insouciance with which the
orthodox Rabbis regard the spread of irreligion, particularly the violation
of the Sabbath, and indulgence in forbidden food, without a
united effort among them to check it by wise and well concocted
measures. Hebrew. There is, I sincerely believe, more taleah
and more real learning among the orthodox than among the Reformers, and yet
they allow this “laissez aller” sent state of things to go on. But
enough of this for the present.

And now for a little Hebrew relating to myself, with
which I beg of you to occupy a trifle of your valuable time.
A brother of mine recently informed me of his having met in London
Mr. Lem Dyer, brother of our lamented friend Mrs. Osterman,

who info mentioned to him that that lady had bequeathed me
and my wife, a legacy of $3000 in her will. It is easy for
you, being in the spot, to ascertain, either by writing to Mrs.
Symonds, formerly Hannah Dyer, at Cincinnati, or by
personal inquiry among her friends the Pollacks, the
truth of my brother's statement. I have foreborne so long
from addressing Mrs. S. not knowing her right address,
that a direct inquiry from me now, would be indelicate.
I prefer you being my agent in this to my brother's being so,
for various reasons. It will be sufficient to quote the
words of Solomon Hebrew. You will be doing me
and your old friend Mrs. N a favor by losing no time
in letting us know Hebrew.

Our Holy days passed off delightfully, full attendances
at Synagogue, great devotion, order, and decorum, and nothing
to ruffle the harmony from Hebrew on the eve
of that day I confirmed 5 young people 3 girls and 2 boys.
Every child almost of 6 or 7 years of age, boy or girl, learns
to read Hebrew, and nearly every lady in Synagogue, particularly
the young and middle aged reads her prayers in that language,
and can follow the leader officiating. Your small Bible

is in every house, and every one of my pupils is furnished
with it. Every Jewish child in school, for I have many
Christian pupils too, learn, to translate Bible and prayer
Book. So you see, tho' we are far from the great
centres of enlightenment, and tho' I am as rusty as an
old door nail, we can compare, as a Congregation,
with the best, and not be ashamed. It would do your
heart good to witness the solemnity and decorum of our
worship. On Hebrew we began at 8 and tho' nothing was
omitted as laid down in the old Portuguese sidder?
we finished at 11. Kippoor we began at 6, and at 6
P.M. I dismissed the congregation. I do not allow
the Shophar to be blown till the whole of the Hebrew is
finished, whereby much confusion and indecency are
avoided. For men I to have it sounded before Hebrew
there would be a rush to leave, by which the whole affect
of the day would be destroyed.

Hebrew, so I defer writing more Hebrew. I hope to
hear that your health is good, in which my dear wife
heartily joins—and with regards to your nieces, and
